message: Add simple package.json
Set up a simple npm test (eslint only) and commit package-lock.json
Set up ESLint (using eslint-config-wikimedia)

Set up monorepo with Yarn

* Sets up this project as a yarn-based monorepo, with subprojects
  organized in the packages/ directory.
* Adds a "workspaces" key to the top-level package.json file; each
  workspace subdir has its own package.json file to track dependencies,
  scripts, etc.
* Checks in the Yarn 2 binary so that all contributors can use the same
  tool to manage the project; Yarn's "workspace-tools" plugin has also been
  added
* Moves the existing devDependencies as workspace dependencies for the
  vue-components workspace; these have been checked in to source control
  in the .yarn/cache directory to support zero-install usage
* Removes the previous .github folder  and .gitignore file for now; we
  can re-introce what we need in a workspace-aware fashion
* Adds a basic README to explain yarn-based workflow

NOTE: After the Yarn monorepo setup was removed, this commit was rewritten
to remove the large binaries in the .yarn/ directory, as well as the
yarn.lock and .pnp.cjs files.
Use tabs

NPM-based workspaces and basic Vite config (#7)

NPM-based workspaces and basic Vite config

* Replaces Yarn with NPM (too many compatibility issues with other libraries)
* Sets up NPM-based workspace management / monorepo structure
* Adds basic Vite config

Set "license" in all package.json files to GPL-2.0+

This matches the string used in WVUI's package.json file.
Configure postcss and enable cross-workspace token imports

Set up Github CI again, and make it run `npm test` in all packages (#5)

* Set up Github CI again, and make it run `yarn run test` in all packages

This also makes running `yarn run test` or `npm test` in the root
directory do what you expect (run the tests for all packages).

* Update to use npm instead of yarn

* Add NPM and Node version restrictions to package.json

* Only run tests in Node 16. Node 12 and 14 don't come with NPM 7.

* Fix the name

Co-authored-by: Eric Gardner <egardner@wikimedia.org>
Merge branch 'main' into postcss

Vitepress setup (#11)

* Basic VitePress setup
- Move docs to docs/ directory
- Configure VitePress
- Set up Wrapper component for component demo formatting
- Set up vue-docgen-cli for automated component usage docs
- Set up simple Button demo
* Add README
* Rename docs package to vitepress
- To prevent confusion between the package and its docs dir
* Update command in README
* Move component demos inside the docs package
* Make Vue a dependency instead of a peerDependency
* Add vue-components as a dependency of the vitepress package
- This allows us to import components directly into markdown files
  instead of relatively
* Fix trailing comma

Co-authored-by: Eric Gardner <egardner@wikimedia.org>
Merge branch 'main' into postcss

Set up eslint (#4)

* vue-component: Set up eslint

- Set up .eslintrc.json with a simple config
- Install packages this config depends on (eslint-config-wikimedia and
  typescript-eslint)
- Also install typescript (because it's needed by typescript-eslint),
  but don't configure it yet
- Add rules to .yarnrc.yml to make eslint's plugin system work with
  yarn-pnp's dependency resolution rules, which are stricter than npm's
- Add settings for VSCode so that it looks for eslint in the right place
- Add eslint as a root-level devDependency so that the yarn-sdk tool
  knows it's being used and generates the VSCode stuff for it

* Update package-lock.json

* Add eslint everywhere and make pass

Set up eslint globally, rather than locally in each package:
- Move eslint and related devDependencies to the top level
- Remove package-level lint commands, instead run one top-level lint
  command
- Create a top-level .eslintrc.json with common rules, which each of the
  package-specific .eslintrc.json files inherits from
This is also how Vue manages linting in their monorepo, and one
advantage is that top-level files (like package.json) are also linted.

* Update README.md for lint command change

Work around lack of support for npm test --workspaces in CI

The --workspaces flag is only supported in NPM >7.14, but our CI uses
NPM 7.5.2. Without support for the --workspaces flag, our implementation
of npm test results in an infinite loop. Work around this by manually
mimicking the functionality of the --workspaces flag.

Bug: T293155
Change-Id: I06427b48f87a0322c89ccbc7f39a175a3caa9731

Icon: Add Icon component and icon system

Based largely on WVUI's icon system, but with some differences.

Add a new package called icons, which contains:
- Icons as .svg files
- Icon types and utilities that support expressing icons as either
  path strings or full SVG strings
- An index file that imports all the icons' SVG files and exports their
  icon definitions
- A custom Vite plugin that imports .svg files as strings, after
  using SVGO to clean up the SVG and a custom SVGO plugin to strip away
  the outer <svg> tag. Also use SVGO to prefix IDs in each icon with the
  name of the icon, to avoid ID collisions when multiple icons are loaded
  on the same page.
- A script that builds the icon definitions as a JSON file
- Jest tests that verify that the type definitions are complete and not
  broken (TypeScript's type definition generation has trouble with the
  .svg file import thing)
- Jest configuration so that it understands how to import .svg files

Add an Icon component that embeds the SVG it's given, and detects the
language and direction at mount time unless they're overridden in
props.

build: Reorganize Vitepress Vite config and package.json

- Move vite.config.ts to the docs/ directory, so that it's actually
  picked up by Vitepress. There's nothing in there yet, but this way

- Remove the Vue plugin from the Vitepress Vite config, otherwise

- Remove build/serve/dev commands that did nothing because they pointed
  to Vite; instead point them to Vitepress
- Run the Vitepress build as part of "npm test"
- Change top-level "docs" command to "docs:dev", add "doc" command that
  builds the docs. This brings Codex in line with other Wikimedia repos
  where "npm run doc" is the usual command to build generated
  documentation.

Change-Id: I7733fd8a5007b4a0efa6abd8c1a465978625aae1

Rename packages so they're suitable for publication to NPM

- packages/vue-components -> packages/codex, named @wikimedia/codex
- packages/icons -> packages/codex-icons, named @wikimedia/codex-icons
- packages/design-tokens -> packages/codex-tokens, named @wikimedia/codex-tokens
- packages/vitepress -> packages/codex-docs

Update imports, workspace names, etc. accordingly.

To avoid eslint failures, create a build-all-if-missing command, and run
it before eslint runs. Otherwise, eslint fails because importing from
'@wikimedia/codex' is considered an error when that package hasn't been
built yet.

Also alias @wikimedia/codex to codex/src/lib.ts in the codex-docs
Vite config, so that the component demos use realistic-looking imports
that people can copy and paste into their code, but hot reloading still
works.

build: Add the @wikimedia/codex-search package

This package doesn't have any source code itself, it just exports the
TypeaheadSearch component from packages/codex. This provides a
slimmed-down build of Codex with only those things relevant for search
use.

Importing from '../codex/src/...' is ugly, but unfortunately required as
it's the only way to make sure that the CSS is tree-shaken. Importing
from '@wikimedia/codex-search' imports none of the CSS, and importing
from ../codex/src/lib.ts (aliased to '@wikimedia/codex-search') imports
all of the CSS in the entire library.

Reuse the Vite config from the codex package, since the only thing
that's different is the library name.

docs: Flag development components, hide them in release docs

Detect whether a component is under development by looking whether it's
in the src/components-wip directory. If it is, add a warning
banner at the top of its documentation page.

If the docs are built with `npm run doc-release`, don't list development
components in the sidebar at all. Building the docs the regular way
(with `npm run doc`) or previewing them with `npm run doc:dev` does
list them in the sidebar, but with a construction emoji symbol to
indicate work in progress status.

Even in the release build, the docs for development components can
still be accessed if you know the URL.

build, styles: Introduce 'stylelint-declaration-strict-value' plugin

Introducing the new 'stylelint-declaration-strict-value' plugin, which
lints against using values that are not in the allowed list –
Codex design tokens, SFC variables and keywords.
The keyword list is based on our current agreements including the
normalization and reset values.

Note,
- that introducing SFC variables on top is preferred over
  `stylelint-disable` rules as it makes identifying token gaps easier
- that some properties are not in the list, as they are providing
  only functional or resetting values, that are not meant to be themed:
-- `content`, `background-repeat` and `position`
- that `background-image` doesn't seem to get caught, see
  `repeating-conic-gradient()` in TokenDemo

Also
- replacing ToggleSwitch's value that's already available as token,
- replacing `font-weight: bold` with available token in toggle-button
  and CardGroupWithThumbnails
- moving one static value into an SFC variable.

An excerpt of properties going to be tackled in a follow-up:
Add more properties to the list
- `background-position`
- `top`, `right`, `bottom`, `left`
- `width`, `height`
- `margin`, `border` & `padding` longhands
- `animation-iteration-count`
- …
A number of tasks have already been filed for the missing propertes.

Change-Id: I82b8b6c6339bd3eca40aa62715c457406038390d

docs: Add banners for main branch and deployment previews

This patch adds a message to each page of the docs site when the
site is built based on the main branch or a gerrit patch for a
deployment preview. Specific changes:

- Adds a new CODEX_BRANCH_DEPLOY env variable so we can easily
  tell if this is a deployment preview
- Adds a new CODEX_DOC_DEV env variable so we can easily tell
  if we're in local development
- Extends VitePress's DefaultTheme.Config type to add properties
  we want to be able to use in components
- Passes boolean `isMainBranch` and `isBranchDeploy properties,
  along with a `patchID` if it's a deployment preview, to the
  theme config
- Uses those properties to determine which message to show
- Adds a new VersionBanner component that displays the proper
  message
- Includes the VersionBanner at the top of the content section
  for most pages, and within the content on the home page

Design notes:

- Since we don't have design precedent for full-width banners at
  the top of the page, I chose to use the CdxMessage component
  instead, The resulting UI is similar to what the Vue 2 docs do
  to inform users of the version and point them to the Vue 3 docs
  (see https://v2.vuejs.org/v2/guide/)
- I made the main branch notice message dismissable since the
  the main branch should only ever be at most 2 weeks ahead of the
  latest release
- I made the branch deploy message a warning and non-dismissable
  since it's critical to help our users avoid mistaking a branch
  deploy instance for the canonical site

Change-Id: I489f1e434f47b6d1de314cbbdfda6260f58993e5

Simplify Codex build process via a JS build script

Introduces a `generateCodexBundle` function which contains
the logic for producing all the variants we need for a given
Codex library build (base, RTL, legacy, and legacy RTL). This
script takes a bundle name and a Vite UserConfig object, and
makes multiple calls to the Vite `build` method to generate
all necessary files. This function currently lives in
build/utils.mjs in the Codex workspace, but in the future we
may move it elsewhere.

Also adds a `build.mjs` file in the Codex workspace which
orchestrates the build process using Vite's JS API and this
new generateCodexBundle method. A similar script has been
added to `codex-docs` (to build the demo bundles) and to
`codex-search` (to build the Typeahead bundles).

Build-specific code has been removed from the vite.config.ts
files; these files are now only needed for development mode.

Potential future improvements: We may want to the following
in follow-up patches (they should be considered out-of-scope
for the patch here):

* Remove the `codex-search` package entirely in favor of
  generating that build from the main `codex` workspace;
  this is a breaking change and would also involve unpublishing
  or archiving the `codex-search` NPM module
* Move the `generateCodexBundle` script and any related shared
  utils or configs into a new "build" or "utils" package so that
  other workspaces within the monorepo can explicitly depend
  on this. Currently there are some cross-workspace imports
  happening that are easy to miss; however this was also the
  case before this patch, so things are not any worse than they
  already were on this account.

Bug: T335323
Change-Id: I4bcfc180ccbc389d50f4545781f0fa85b873707d

build: Update 'stylelint-config-wikimedia' and 'stylelint' plugins

This patch also removes 'stylelint' package itself and relies on
stylelint-config-wikimedia's dependency.

Note that stylelint v15.0.0+, which is referenced by
stylelint-config-wikimedia, requires a change to 76 rules that enforce
stylistic conventions. Hence this patch also adds 'stylelint-stylistic'
package that continues with our current conventions.
Longer-term we should revisit Prettier for those conventions overall.

Also note, that `rem` are an allowed unit again, therefore we can
remove stylelint disable on one occasion in VitePress custom.css.

dependency instead.

Note, this is currently throwing warnings by newly added
'plugin:security/recommended' in v0.25.0.

build: Update TypeScript, eslint, jest, etc

jest: 27.3.1 -> 29.7.0
ts-jest: 27.0.5 -> 29.1.1
@vue/vue3-jest: 27.0.0-alpha.1 -> 29.2.6
@vue/test-utils: 2.0.1 -> 2.4.1
@types/jest: 27.0.2 -> 29.5.6
eslint-plugin-jest: 27.2.1 -> 27.6.0
eslint-plugin-cypress: 2.12.1 -> 2.15.1
typescript: 4.9.4 -> 5.2.2
vue-tsc: 1.0.13 -> 1.8.22
@rollup/plugin-typescript: 11.1.0 -> 11.1.5
@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin: 5.49.0 -> 6.9.0
@typescript-eslint/parser: 5.49.0 -> 6.9.0

Also:
- Add a "name" property to package.json files that didn't have one;
  otherwise npm crashes when trying to report peer dependency errors.
- Add explicit versions of eslint, eslint-plugin-jsdoc and
  eslint-plugin-vue; this is needed to make sure they're all in sync,
  because eslint has a terrible habit of breaking interfaces in minor
  releases and plugins don't accurately express which eslint versions
  they work with
- Add jest to the top-level package.json explicitly, otherwise
  eslint-plugin-jest can't figure out which version of jest is in use
- Add jest-environment-jsdom, jest doesn't pull this in by default
  anymore
- Update jest config and plugins for breaking changes in jest
- Update tests for breaking changes in jest
    - Spying on an instance method doesn't seem to work anymore; delete
      these tests since we shouldn't be doing that anyway
    - Don't assert the exception messages in the Tabs tests; a different
      exception is thrown earlier now. This might be because throwing
      exceptions in setup() is kind of weird.
- Update code for new typescript-eslint rules, mainly:
    - Prefer ?? over ||
    - Prefer foo?.bar over foo && foo.bar
- Reduce coverage threshold in codex-docs to keep tests passing

Change-Id: Ibf75c65748450eddf6074903e2b902014db62f4d

build: Update eslint-config-wikimedia 0.25.1 -> 0.26.0

- Disable the no-missing-import rule in TypeScript and Vue files. This
  rule dropped support for the tryExtensions option, so it no longer
  understands that './foo' means foo.ts . We don't need it anyway,
  because TypeScript also checks imports.
- Various minor tweaks to make new rules pass

between our version of postcss and the (more recent) one that Vite pulls

build: Publish the sandbox on doc.wikimedia.org

We were already publishing the sandbox as part of each patch's Netlify
preview, at URLs like
https://1032082--wikimedia-codex.netlify.app/sandbox . But there was no
way to view the sandbox for the main branch.

This patch publishes the sandbox everywhere that we publish the docs
site:
- For patches, on Netlify as above
- For the main branch, at https://doc.wikimedia.org/codex/main/sandbox
- For the latest release, at https://doc.wikimedia.org/codex/latest/sandbox
- For every release, at https://doc.wikimedia.org/codex/v1.6.1/sandbox
